item.title: Galois Cohomology I
item.description: During the winter term in 2022, I’m TAing the course Galois Cohomology I by Prof. Alexander Schmidt. More details tba.

misc An étale homotopy-theoretic reformulation of the Section Conjecture (2021) Master’s thesis. | pdf Computing simple factors of certain Jacobian varieties over finite fields (2019) Bachelor’s thesis. | pdf teaching Winter 2022 TA: Galois Cohomology I Summer 2022 GAUS AG: The Grothendieck conjecture for affine curves Seminar: Galois and fundamental groups

item.title: Galois and Fundamental Groups
item.description: Together with Marius Leonhardt I’m supervising a seminar on Galois and fundamental groups. The announcement (in german) is here. If you’re interested, subscribe via MÜSLI or send us an email. When? Thursdays, 02:15pm - 03:45pm Where? Mathematikon, SR 6 (Group A) and SR 7 (Group B) Contact: tholzschuh[at]mathi.uni-heidelberg.de mleonhardt[at]mathi.uni-heidelberg.de Handouts of all the talks can be found MaMpf.

item.title: The Grothendieck conjecture for affine curves
item.description: Together with Jakob Stix I’m organizing a GAUS-AG on Tamagawa’s seminal paper The Grothendieck conjecture for affine curves. A detailed programme can be found here. When? Roughly every two weeks on Wednesday. Where? We’re rotating between Heidelberg and Frankfurt. Check out the programme for specific dates and places. Contact: tholzschuh[at]mathi.uni-heidelberg.de stix[at]math.uni-frankfurt.de

item.title: Declarative and reproducible system and user management with NixOS
item.description: I’ve been using NixOS as my main operating system for quite some time now. As I recently upgraded my computer equipment by acquiring a new laptop, I decided that it’s time to invest some more time into further capitalizing on the features of NixOS. The main purpose of this post is to collect all the things I learned while doing so in a single place so that I’ll always be able to look it up again if need be.

item.title: Using LaTeX with Hakyll
item.description: Since Hakyll is tightly integrated with Pandoc, it’s easy to use LaTeX with Hakyll by enabling Pandoc’s LaTeX compile features. Most explanations I found online, like this one, seem to be quite outdated though and they don’t work verbatim. The basic idea still is to set up a custom pandoc compiler using the pandocCompilerWith :: ReaderOptions -> WriterOptions -> Compiler (Item String) function, but the internals used in the WriterOptions have changed.

item.title: Blüdhaven
item.description: History Blüdhaven was a former whaling town, which was officially incorporated as a “Commonwealth” in 1912. The town had a generally poor socio-economic populace, owing in part to failed efforts to transform itself into a manufacturing and shipping center.

item.title: Hydra
item.description: Motto Cut off one head and two will take their place

item.description: A long time ago in a galaxy far, far away…. A project was planned, but never completed
